It's difficult to provide an exact statistic for how much food production decreased during Stalin's reign, as the situation varied significantly depending on the specific time period and region. However, there were certainly significant food shortages and famines during the early years of Stalin's rule, particularly in the early 1930s.

One of the most devastating famines occurred in Ukraine in 1932-33, known as the Holodomor, which was caused in large part by Stalin's policies of collectivization and industrialization. During this period, millions of people died from hunger and malnutrition, and food production in Ukraine and other parts of the Soviet Union decreased significantly.

Overall, while food production did not decrease consistently throughout Stalin's reign, there were certainly significant periods of decline and disruption, particularly in the early years of collectivization and industrialization.
